data.title: Neighborhood Bayou a hit
data.text: If you're looking for authentic Cajun cuisine, a lot of variety and prices that are easy on the pocket, Flatland's won't disappoint. This neighborhood nook offers a number of tasty meals in a festive and fun Cajun bayou atmosphere. I had a red fish dinner and my wife had a pasta dish and both were terrific accompanied by their recommended micro brew draft beers. We'll be returning soon.

data.title: Not New Orleans
data.text:
Our recent visit to Flatlands on a Thursday evening was very average.  Admittedly, our visit followed a recent trek to New Orleans and all of the flavors and ambiance of the true bayou.  

Flatlands is now the third (by our count) restaurant to try to make it off the main strip near downtown Alpharetta.  While the restaurant and grounds are charming, the service/staff was fair, and the food was average too.  The shrimp & grits was okay and the ribs were fine, but nothing on the menu will likely spark a return.  Keep trying though.

data.title: Blackened shrimp salad
data.text: This was my second visit . I had the blackened shrimp salad . Simple my divine ! Dried figs , cheese (goat I think), bacon, kale, spinach , red onions , and perfectly blackened shrimp dressed lightly . Last visit I had the house gumbo . Also delicious . Love the building , great service by Jennifer. Half price bottled wine on Tuesday !

data.title: Delightful find
data.text: This restaurant is tucked behind the Mezz Spa one block north of downtown Alpharetta.  We found it accidentally one day while walking and are glad we did.  The New Orleans style food is delicious and prepared with a flare.  There is plenty of seating both indoors and out.  The staff are all well trained and helpful.

data.title: Finally a WIN in downtown Alpharetta!
data.text: We've been sorely disappointed with all the hyped up places in Alpharetta. Flatlands did not let us down. It is a little hard to find. It's behind another business on Main across from the Church, but I promise it's worth the effort. The ginger peach martini was excellent and packed a punch. Jim had the blueberry mule and it was tasty. I had the jambalaya special and really liked it. It was spicy but just the right amount of heat with plump shrimp and sausage. Jim had the Shrimp and Andouille with red beans an rice. It was good too. There was so much we wanted to try on the menu we will be back!  They are starting brunch around Halloween. Can't wait to try that. Don't wait else where, walk half a block and try these guys out!

data.title: Hidden Treasure
data.text: Although difficult to locate, this restaurant did not disappoint.We had several questions about the menu. Our server, Anna, was quite knowledgeable. I had a small Caesar Salad and the Seafood Platter. I asked that my fried foods be lightly battered and lightly fried and that is how they were prepared - all quite tasty. My wife had the Cajun Shrimp Pasta and found it to be plentiful delicious. Our friend ordered the Blackened Catfish which he enjoyed as well. All alcoholic drinks we ordered were well prepared. Prices were reasonable.

data.title: Excellent!  Must do in Alpharetta
data.text: My fiancé and I have been twice since this place opened about a month ago.  We haven't tried everything on the menu but what we have tried has been phenomenal!  Get the crab dip and the Cajun shrimp pasta...  you can't go wrong!  I have yet to try their chargrilled oysters but I will soon.
